How does it happen that one
farmer fails while his neighbor at-
tains tlie fullest success when each
has an equal opportunity, was the
question that Dr. W. T. L. Talia-
ferro, professor of farm manage-
ment, determined to solve back in
1890, He knew the possibilities in
farming for when he was but 15
years old he began to actively man-
age his fathers’ two farms on one
of which he was born in 1856.
Management and improved meth-
ods, he felt, was the solution of his
problem. He studied the methods
of prosperous farmers and publish-
ed the results of his investigations
in the newspaper of which he was
the editor. Later, when he became
professor ot Agriculture at the Ma-
ryland Agricultural College at its
reorganization in 1892, he entered
upon a larger field of endeavor.
Helps the* Farmers.
He was one of the pioneers in the
propoganda for improved seed corn
and the growing of alfalfa in Mary-
land, by which immense sums have
been added to the agricultural rev-
enue of the State. To promote this
and other similar movements from
1900 to 1906 he acted as Agricul-
turist of the Maryland Experiment
Station until the insistent demands
of his students caused him to give
up this part of his work. From
1915 to 1917, Dr. Taliaferro was
acting dean of the Division of Agri-
culture at College Park.
Dr. Taliaferro gained the rudi-
ments of his education in private
schools, meanwhile working on the
farm. Matriculating at William and
Mary College, he was graduated in
1876, valedictorian of his class,
with the degree of B. A.
University of Maryland conferred
upon him his Doctor ot Science de-
gree.
For five years succeeding his
graduation, he was principal of the
graded school, Gloucester, Va„
meanwhile managing one of his fath-
er’s farms.
Goins to Bel Air.
In 18 81 he accepted the Princi-
palship of the Bel Air Academy, in
Hartford County. He resigned
there to accept the position of act-
ing editor of the Hartford Democrat
in 188 6. Meanwhile he kept up his
interest in agricultural matters, be-
ing a member and secretary of the
Fallston Farmers Club and taking
a leading part in organizing the
first series of Farmer’s Institutes
over held in Maryland. While at
Bel Air, Prof. Taliaferro was active
in the organization ot Company D.
First Regiment, Maryland Nation-
al Guard, of which he was later
made captain.
From 1903 until the reorganiza-
tion of the state departments in
1923, Prof. Taliaferro was a mem-
ber of the Board of Government and
Secretary-Treasurer of the Maryland
State Weather Service.
Prof. Taliaferro, who resides in
College Park, is a Past Master ot
tlie Masons; a Past Master of the
Grange; a member ot the National
Education Association, Beta Theta
Pi, Phi Beta Kappa, and Phi Kappa
Phi Fraternities: a member of the
Association of Farm Economics, the
Association for the Advancement of
Science, the Agronomy Association,
and the American Meteorological
Society.
U. of M.
